text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

Inauguration Day is so
symbolic of everything
that this nation stands for.
I, Franklin Delano Roosevelt--
I, Dwight D. Eisenhower--
I, John Fitzgerald Kennedy--
I, Lyndon Baines Johnson--
Do solemnly swear--
That I will faithfully execute--

the office of President
of the United States.

What makes Inauguration
Day so powerful
is you are witnessing--
a peaceful transition of power.

And the fact that we are
all in that moment together,
focused on that moment--

Such an admiration for
our political process
and the president at the time--

And then, not only
is there the what's

going on in that
exact moment, there's
also the connection to history.

And will to the
best of my ability--
Preserve, protect--
And defend--

The Constitution of
the United States.
So help you God?
So help me God.
Congratulations, Mr. President.

Everyday I showed up at
work at the White House
I earned zero dollars.

But every day I
walked down West exec.

and would see the West Wing
and see the White House

and then hang a right into the
Eisenhower executive office
building.

And every morning
seeing that White House,

you think oh man, this
is where I get to work.
This is why I'm doing this work.

This work is really
important to me.

Learning about the
entire U.S. economy

is an overwhelming
amount of information.

And so it's a really fast paced
and challenging environment.

It's also a place where
you sit atop a system.

You're on the route up
to the president in terms

of analyzing the U.S.
economy and distilling it

down into something
actionable, and I really

liked the potential of the
job to be able to steer things

one degree at a
time towards a world

that is more desirable
for all of us.

What I was so amazed
to learn is how

really, truly passionate
folks at the White House

are about getting things
done in a productive way

and how disinterested they
often are in getting the credit.

To get anything done, you
really can't get it done alone.

You have to think
through how we're

going to get all
of the stakeholders

on board towards this vision
and this goal that we have,

and once we have
that coalition, how

are we actually going to
mobilize them towards action?

Having access and exposure
to someone like Hank Paulson

really at the very
beginning of my career

was transformational
in so many ways,

but I think it made
me feel like anything

was possible in my own career
in a way that I hadn't before.

You sort of realize
that the office

and the jobs you're doing are
so much bigger than you are.

It also makes you really believe
that you as an individual

and you as a small
group can have
a huge effect on the world.

What's different about
the White House Office

is that every single person is a
representative of the president
himself.

They serve at his
pleasure and they really

embody the staffers'
creed of, before choice

is made argue for
your point of view,

but once it's made it's
your job to carry it out.

A piece of advice that
Joe Biden gave me was you

need to know which issues
you're prepared to lose on.

They call it the people's house
and it really truly is that.

And I don't think I realized how
much it was until I got there.

I came from a first generation
American background.
My parents weren't born here.

Neither of them graduated
with a high school degree.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

I don't think one person
defines this country.

You have this
transfer of power that
happens peaceably and on time.

I think what the President-elect
and leaders across the world

need to do is just really
understand what it means

to be empathetic
and to understand

what their constituents
are going through.

You figure in a
different country

where a candidate loses the
vote by 2.5 million voters
and yet wins, what might happen?

It's really helpful and
important for all of us

to be able to engage
with one another

and talk about
what we're thinking

about with the upcoming
administration.

I think the most important
advice anyone can give

is to think through
clearly what is in the best
interest of this country.

Patriotism has to do
with love for country

and not love for party or even
love for a particular policy.
